tags.description: STB-3.M.2: Recycling is one way to reduce the current global demand on minerals, but this process is energy-intensive and can be costly.

tags.label: STB-3.M.3
tags.description: STB-3.M.3: Composting is the process of organic matter such as food scraps, paper, and yard waste decomposing. The product of this decomposition can be used as fertilizer. Drawbacks to composting include odor and rodents.

tags.label: STB-3.M.4
tags.description: STB-3.M.4: E-waste can be reduced by recycling and reuse. E-wastes may contain hazardous chemicals, including heavy metals such as lead and mercury, which can leach from landfills into groundwater if they are not disposed of properly.

tags.label: STB-3.M.5
tags.description: STB-3.M.5: Landfill mitigation strategies range from burning waste for energy to restoring habitat on former landfills for use as parks.

tags.label: STB-3.M.6
tags.description: STB-3.M.6: The combustion of gases produced from decomposition of organic material in landfills can be used to turn turbines and generate electricity. This process reduces landfill volume.

tags.label: STB-3.N
tags.description: STB-3.N: Describe best practices in sewage treatment.

tags.label: STB-3.N.1
tags.description: STB-3.N.1: Primary treatment of sewage is the physical removal of large objects, often through the use of screens and grates, followed by the settling of solid waste in the bottom of a tank.

tags.label: STB-3.N.2
tags.description: STB-3.N.2: Secondary treatment is a biological process in which bacteria break down organic matter into carbon dioxide and inorganic sludge, which settles in the bottom of a tank. The tank is aerated to increase the rate at which the bacteria breaks down the organic matter.

tags.label: STB-3.N.3
tags.description: STB-3.N.3: Tertiary treatment is the use of ecological or chemical processes to remove any pollutants left in the water after primary and secondary treatment.

tags.label: STB-3.N.4
tags.description: STB-3.N.4: Prior to discharge, the treated water is exposed to one or more disinfectants (usually, chlorine, ozone, or UV light) to kill bacteria.

tags.label: STB-4
tags.description: STB-4: Local and regional human activities can have impacts at the global level.

tags.label: STB-4.A
tags.description: STB-4.A: Explain the importance of stratospheric ozone to life on Earth.

tags.label: STB-4.A.1
tags.description: STB-4.A.1: The stratospheric ozone layer is important to the evolution of life on Earth and the continued health and survival of life on Earth.

tags.label: STB-4.A.2
tags.description: STB-4.A.2: Stratospheric ozone depletion is caused by anthropogenic factors, such as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), and natural factors, such as the melting of ice crystals in the atmosphere at the beginning of the Antarctic spring.

tags.label: STB-4.A.3
tags.description: STB-4.A.3: A decrease in stratospheric ozone increases the UV rays that reach the Earth's surface. Exposure to UV rays can lead to skin cancer and cataracts in humans.

tags.label: STB-4.B
tags.description: STB-4.B: Describe chemicals used to substitute for chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

tags.label: STB-4.B.1
tags.description: STB-4.B.1: Ozone depletion can be mitigated by replacing ozone-depleting chemicals with substitutes that do not deplete the ozone layer. Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) are one such replacement, but some are strong greenhouse gases.

tags.label: STB-4.C
tags.description: STB-4.C: Identify the greenhouse gases.

tags.label: STB-4.C.1
tags.description: STB-4.C.1: The principal greenhouse gases are carbon dioxide, methane, water vapor, nitrous oxide, and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

tags.label: STB-4.C.2
tags.description: STB-4.C.2: While water vapor is a greenhouse gas, it doesn't contribute significantly to global climate change because it has a short residence time in the atmosphere.

tags.label: STB-4.C.3
tags.description: STB-4.C.3: The Greenhouse Effect results in the surface temperature necessary for life on Earth to exist.

tags.label: STB-4.D
tags.description: STB-4.D: Identify the sources and potency of the greenhouse gases.

tags.label: STB-4.D.1
tags.description: STB-4.D.1: Carbon dioxide, which has a global warming potential (GWP) of 1, is used as a reference point for the comparison of different greenhouse gases and their impacts on global climate change. Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) have the highest GWP, followed by nitrous oxide, then methane.

tags.label: STB-4.E
tags.description: STB-4.E: Identify the threats to human health and the environment posed by an increase in greenhouse gases.

tags.label: STB-4.E.1
tags.description: STB-4.E.1: Global climate change, caused by excess greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, can lead to a variety of environmental problems including rising sea levels resulting from melting ice sheets and ocean water expansion, and disease vectors spreading from the tropics toward the poles. These problems can lead to changes in population dynamics and population movements in response.

tags.label: STB-4.F
tags.description: STB-4.F: Explain how changes in climate, both short- and long-term, impact ecosystems.

tags.label: STB-4.F.1
tags.description: STB-4.F.1: The Earth has undergone climate change throughout geologic time, with major shifts in global temperatures causing periods of warming and cooling as recorded with CO2 data and ice cores.

tags.label: STB-4.F.10
tags.description: STB-4.F.10: One consequence of the loss of ice and snow in polar regions is the effect on species, who depend on the ice for habitat and food.

tags.label: STB-4.F.2
tags.description: STB-4.F.2: Effects of climate change include rising temperatures, melting permafrost and sea ice, rising sea levels, and displacement of coastal populations.

tags.label: STB-4.F.3
tags.description: STB-4.F.3: Marine ecosystems are affected by changes in sea level, some positively, such as in newly created habitats on now-flooded continental shelves, and some negatively, such as deeper communities that may no longer be in the photic zone of seawater.

tags.label: STB-4.F.4
tags.description: STB-4.F.4: Winds generated by atmospheric circulation help transport heat throughout the Earth. Climate change may change circulation patterns, as temperature changes may impact Hadley cells and the jet stream.

tags.label: STB-4.F.5
tags.description: STB-4.F.5: Oceanic currents, or the ocean conveyor belt, carry heat throughout the world. When these currents change, it can have a big impact on global climate, especially in coastal regions.

tags.label: STB-4.F.6
tags.description: STB-4.F.6: Climate change can affect soil through changes in temperature and rainfall, which can impact soil's viability and potentially increase erosion.

tags.label: STB-4.F.7
tags.description: STB-4.F.7: Earth's polar regions are showing faster response times to global climate change because ice and snow in these regions reflect the most energy back out to space, leading to a positive feedback loop.

tags.label: STB-4.F.8
tags.description: STB-4.F.8: As the Earth warms, this ice and snow melts, meaning less solar energy is radiated back into space and instead is absorbed by the Earth's surface. This in turn causes more warming of the polar regions.

tags.label: STB-4.F.9
tags.description: STB-4.F.9: Global climate change response time in the Arctic is due to positive feedback loops involving melting sea ice and thawing tundra, and the subsequent release of greenhouse gases like methane.

tags.label: STB-4.G
tags.description: STB-4.G: Explain the causes and effects of ocean warming.

tags.label: STB-4.G.1
tags.description: STB-4.G.1: Ocean warming is caused by the increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.

tags.label: STB-4.G.2
tags.description: STB-4.G.2: Ocean warming can affect marine species in a variety of ways, including loss of habitat, and metabolic and reproductive changes.

tags.label: STB-4.G.3
tags.description: STB-4.G.3: Ocean warming is causing coral bleaching, which occurs when the loss of algae within corals cause the corals to bleach white. Some corals recover and some die.

tags.label: STB-4.H
tags.description: STB-4.H: Explain the causes and effects of ocean acidification.

tags.label: STB-4.H.1
tags.description: STB-4.H.1: Ocean acidification is the decrease in pH of the oceans, primarily due to increased CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere, and can be expressed as chemical equations.

tags.label: STB-4.H.2
tags.description: STB-4.H.2: As more CO2 is released into the atmosphere, the oceans, which absorb a large part of that CO2, become more acidic.

tags.label: STB-4.H.3
tags.description: STB-4.H.3: Anthropogenic activities that contribute to ocean acidification are those that lead to increased CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere: burning of fossil fuels, vehicle emissions, and deforestation.

tags.label: STB-4.H.4
tags.description: STB-4.H.4: Ocean acidification damages coral because acidification makes it difficult for them to form shells, due to the loss of calcium carbonate.
